vacant.translation[0].definitions[0].def: a vacant seat, building, room, or piece of land is empty and available for someone to use
vacant.translation[0].definitions[0].exa: Only a few apartments were still vacant.
There was only a vacant lot (=empty unused area of land in a city) where her house used to be.
vacant.translation[0].definitions[0].not: In everyday English, people usually say that a seat or room is free rather than vacant:
vacant.translation[0].definitions[1].def: a job or position in an organization that is vacant is available for someone to start doing
vacant.translation[0].definitions[1].not: situations vacant British English (=the part of a newspaper where jobs are advertised)
vacant.translation[0].definitions[1].exa: He was offered the position of headmaster when it fell vacant.
vacant.translation[1].definitions[0].def: property that is vacant is not being used and may be available to rent or buy
vacant.translation[1].definitions[0].exa: The committee recommended that factories should be sited on vacant land in small towns rather than in villages or the open countryside.
The number of vacant properties for all housing applicants has fallen during the same period.
vacant.translation[1].definitions[1].def: vacant jobs or positions in a company are available for someone to start doing
vacant.translation[1].definitions[1].exa: She turned down two job offers before accepting the vacant post of deputy administrator.
Nine seats have beenleft vacant by recent board resignations.
vacant.translation[1].definitions[2].def: the part of a newspaper in which jobs are advertised
